comments:
Sociology is the systematic study of the groups and societies in which people live. In this introductory sociology course, students examine and analyze how social structures and cultures are created, maintained, and affect behavior. The course deconstructs our social interactions and examines what theory and research can tell about human social behavior. 

Overall, students found the readings and books helped make the class “an excellent experience.” One student explained how the book “opened (his) eyes to the problems our world faces today.” Although the readings were interesting, a “large quantity of reading is required” for this course. 

Students referred to Professor Zuberi as a “UPenn All-Star and highly educated individual” and a “brilliant mind.” However, many students felt he was an “unreachable resource” due to the lack of uniform office hours. Professor Zuberi enjoyed triggering “controversial class discussion” in lecture and promoting student participation.

This is an introductory level course and is open to freshman and upperclassmen. Several students taking this course were interested in a Sociology major or minor. This course fulfills the College Society Sector requirement as well as Cultural Diversity in the U.S. The difficulty of the course stems from the large amount of reading and possibility of pop quizzes.
